children.name: when sth or sb makes you laugh
comic b1
children.definition: comic intended to entertain people and make them laugh: hài
examples: streep provided one of the best comic performances of her career.
comic writer/actor/performer etcone who writes or performs things that make you laugh
like all comic writers, shaw was fascinated by the gap between appearance and reality.
comic verse/songthat entertains you and makes you laugh
then gertie got up on the stage and delighted us all by singing a comic song.
comic reliefsth funny in a serious story
in shakespeare’s henry iv, the character of falstaff provides us with a little comic relief.

children.name: funny a1
children.definition: funny sth or sb that is funny makes you laugh: buồn cười
examples: it was the funniest story i’d ever heard.
he can be pretty funny when he’s had a few drinks.
the goat was chasing mark round and round the field - it was so funny.
look funny
you look really funny in that hat.
hilariously/hysterically funny
did you like ‘notting hill’? i thought it was hilariously funny.

children.name: make sb laugh a2
children.definition: make sb laugh to make sb laugh, for example by telling a joke or doing sth funny: làm ai đó cười
examples: i must tell jerry what you said - it’ll make him laugh.
charlie chaplin was a great actor with a wonderful ability to make people laugh.
it always makes me laugh when you look at me like that.

children.name: amusing b1
children.definition: amusing especially written funny and entertaining enough to make you smile.amusingis more formal thanfunny. it is often used when something is a little funny and makes you smile, rather than laugh :: vui, gây cười
examples: i like a newspaper with one or two amusing articles, as well as all the serious stuff.
he was a really special person, gentle and amusing at the same time.
highly amusing
my mother was embarrassed, but i found the situation highly amusing.
a highly amusing film
mildly/vaguely amusing(= a little amusing, but not very )
a mildly amusing spectacle
an amusing story/anecdote/incident etc
the book is full of amusing stories about his childhood.
find sth/sb amusing
i don’t find his jokes at all amusing .
mrs denton didn’t find it amusing when i spilt all the paint on the floor.
register
in everyday english, people usually sayfunnyrather thanamusing:

children.name: humorous c1
children.definition: humorous intended to be amusing, little funny- use this especially about stories, descriptions, songs, and other things that people write: khôi hài, hài hước
examples: the book is a humorous account of a young man’s travels in south america.
it was a brilliant speech - clear, precise and humorous.
humorous birthday cards.
her latest book is a humorous look at teenage life.
register
in everyday english, people usually say something isfunnyrather thanhumorous:

children.name: witty b2
children.definition: witty using words in a clever and amusing way: hóm hỉnh, dí dỏm
examples: sam is intelligent, witty, and great fun to be with.
i enjoyed the play - it had a clever plot and a very witty script.
a witty comment/remark
he was witty and very charming.
wit[c] an intelligent person who is good at being funny in clever or original ways: người dí dỏm, hóm hỉnh
rochester was well known as a wit in society circles.
a dozen writers and wits used to gather at the algonquin hotel for lunch.

children.name: hilarious c1
children.definition: hilarious extremely funny - use this about situations, jokes, and stories, but not about people: vui nhộn
examples: our attempts at dancing were hilarious - we all kept tripping over each other.
the hilarious bbc comedy series ‘absolutely fabulous’
he didn't like the film at all - i thought it was hilarious.
the children thought it was hilarious.
the movie has some hilarious scenes.
it was hysterical! you should have seen his face!

children.name: comical x
children.definition: comical especially written funny in a strange or silly way – often used when something is not intended to be funny: tức cười, lố bịch
examples: it was quite comical watching him trying to dance.
her own comical attempts at painting.
carlo looked so comical, striding along in a coat which nearly touched the ground.
the puffin is an unusual sea bird, and there is something almost comical about the way it moves and looks.
lizzie, bouncing along on the donkey, made a comical sight. comically [adverb]
he bowed comically and asked my sister to dance.

children.name: light-hearted
children.definition: funny in a gentle way, and often about a subject that is usually serious : vui vẻ
examples: the programme is a light-hearted look at recent political events.
we always try to keep our newsletter light-hearted, so that people will enjoy it.
the light-hearted way in which the author has approached this book should take some of the hard work out of trying to lose weight.
take a light-heartedlook at sth
the film takes a light-hearted look at life in prison.
light-heartedly[adv] một cách vui vẻ
somehow, moore manages to deal light-heartedly with subjects such as death and illness.

children.name: be a laugh x
children.definition: be a laugh informal if a person or activity is a laugh, they are amusing and give you a lot of fun: hài hước, vui nhộn
examples: there were about 100 people there and it was a laugh from beginning to end .
"how was the party?" "oh, it was a laugh."
a good/ real laughspoken buồn cười
wait until you meet tony. he’s a real laugh.
you'd like sharon - she's a good laugh.
be a laugh a minutebe very amusing rất thích thú
we all had to sleep in one tent and it was a laugh a minute.

children.name: be a hoot x
children.definition: be a hoot informal if a person, situation, performance, film etc is a hoot, they are very funny and enjoyable: rất vui vẻ, “còi”
examples: the movie has a script that is smartly funny, and hugh grant is a hoot!
at the end of the day, there was the moms’ soccer match, which was a hoot!

children.name: playful x
children.definition: playful actions or behaviour that are playful are not serious, but they are fun and friendly: tinh nghịch
examples: he gave me a playful slap on the shoulder.
she tried to sound playful but somehow the words came out the wrong way.
playfully[adverb] một cách tinh nghịch
toby laughed, playfully telling her off.

children.name: facetious x
children.definition: facetious making jokes or trying to be funny in a clever or unkind way that people think is annoying :
examples: don’t be so facetious!
facetious comments
at the risk of sounding facetious, who really cares about what happens?
the speech saying drug users should be shot was clearly facetious, but it contained a serious point.
facetiously[adv] một cách khôi hài
‘what would we do without him?’ said chuck facetiously.

children.name: flippant x
children.definition: flippant not being serious about sth that should be taken seriously, so that people think you do not care: khiếm nhã, suồng sã, chớt nhã
examples: people ask me if i’m related to him, and my answer is usually a flippant ‘no, but i wish i were.’
when asked what is wrong with the economy, analysts reply ‘not enough money.’ this answer is not as flippant as it sounds.
sorry if that sounded flippant or heartless - it wasn’t meant to be.
flippantly[adv] một cách suồng sả
‘it’s only money,’ said gabriella flippantly. ‘here today and gone tomorrow!’

children.name: tongue-in-cheek x
children.definition: tongue-in-cheek a remark, statement etc that is tongue-in-cheek is intended as a joke but is said or written in a serious or sincere way :
examples: his tongue-in-cheek articles are brilliantly funny and very political.

children.name: the quality in sb or sth that makes them funny
humour b1
children.definition: humourukhumorus  the quality or thing in a situation, book, remark etc that makes it funny: tính hài hước
examples: everyone laughed except dad, who obviously didn’t appreciate the humour of the situation.
the most popular children’s books are ones that have plenty of humor in them.
he failed to see the humour of the situation.
sb’s brand of humour(= the type of jokes, funny stories etc that a particular person likes or tells )their brand of humour isn't to everyone's taste.
a flash/trace/touch of humour(= a very small amount of humour )she replied with a rare flash of humour.
black/dark humour(= jokes, funny stories etc about the unpleasant parts of life )the tone of the film is light but there are moments of black humour.
gallows humour(= jokes, funny stories etc which make very unpleasant or dangerous things seem funny)it was the kind of gallows humor that medical students love.
schoolboy humour(= jokes, funny stories etc that are silly and rude but not offensive )the schoolboy humour appealed to him.
dry/deadpan humour(= when someone makes it seem as if they are being serious, but really they are being funny )his serious demeanour lends itself to deadpan humour.
wry humour(= when someone makes something seem both funny and sad )he wrote with wry humour about his time in a turkish prison.
gentle humour(= jokes or stories that do not offend anyone )the plays uses gentle humor to make a strong point.
self-deprecating humour(= jokes, funny stories etc in which you criticize or make fun of yourself )her self-deprecating humour made the audience howl with laughter.
see/appreciate the humour(= understand that something is funny )i may have been wet and covered in mud, but i could still see the humour in the situation.

children.name: comedy x
children.definition: comedy the quality in a situation, book, film, television programme etc that is intended to entertain people and make them laugh: tính khôi hài , hài hước
examples: can’t you see the comedy of the situation?
it was a brilliant play - full of drama, and both sadness and comedy.
much of the comedy in pratchett’s books comes from the clever way he plays around with words and ideas.

children.name: wit c1
children.definition: wit the ability to use words and express ideas in a clever and amusing way, especially when it is shown in conversation or writing: tài hóm hỉnh ,óc dí dỏm
examples: a woman of great wit and charm.
her conversation sparkled with her own subtle blend of wit and charm.
he seemed to have everything you could want in a man -- intelligence, wit, good looks and charm.
the wit and irony of the original novel has been lost in the film version.
quick/dry/sharp etc wit
his sharp wit had them all smiling.
he was known for his dry wit.

children.name: the ability to realize when sth is funny
sense of humour b1
children.definition: sense of humouruk /sense of humorus  your ability to understand and enjoy jokes, funny situations etc: óc hài hước
examples: mr hardman was a popular teacher, renowned for his sense of humor.
have a (good/great/strange etc) sense of humour có một bộc óc hài hước tốt, tuyệt vời, kì lạ
i like ann - she has such a good sense of humour.
lose your sense of humour
maybe i’m losing my sense of humor but i didn’t find it at all funny.

children.name: can take a joke x
children.definition: can take a joke especially spoken to be able to laugh and not get angry when other people make jokes about you or do sth that makes you look stupid: biết đùa
examples: i hope he can take a joke - have you seen what they’ve done to his car?
you may find army life difficult if you can’t take a joke.

children.name: see the funny side of a1
children.definition: see the funny side of to realize that a situation that seems to be bad is also funny:
examples: i explained that it was all my fault and fortunately she saw the funny side of the situation.
see the funny side of it
as a teacher, things often go wrong, and you have to be able to see the funny side of it.
see the funny side of life
a cartoonist’s job is all about making people see the funny side of life.

children.name: can laugh x
children.definition: can laugh to be able to laugh and joke about your own mistakes and faults or about past experiences which did not seem funny when they were happening : biết đùa
examples: we can laugh now, but at the time it seemed like the end of the world.
can laugh at yourself
don’t take yourself too seriously -- it’s a good thing if you can laugh at yourself sometimes.

children.name: to pretend that sth is true as a joke
jokingly x
children.definition: jokingly if you say sth jokingly you say it to amuse people, and do not really mean it seriously:
examples: braden jokingly refers to her daughter as ‘the demon.’

children.name: you’re having me on x
children.definition: you’re having me onuk/you’re putting me onus  spoken say this when you think sb is trying to make you believe sth that is not true:
examples: come on, you guys, you’re putting me on, right?
he makes £80,000 a year? you’re having me on.

children.name: be pulling sb’s leg x
children.definition: be pulling somebody’s leg/biː ˌpʊlɪŋ somebodyˈs ˈleg/  informal to try to make someone believe something that is not true, as a friendly joke:
examples: ▪ is all this really true, or are you pulling my leg?
▪ you don’t really have to buy tickets. i was just pulling your leg.

children.name: wind sb up x
children.definition: wind somebody up/ˌwaɪnd somebody ˈʌp/  british to say something that is untrue, or do or say something to deliberately annoy someone, as a joke:
examples: ▪ i was only winding you up - don’t take it so seriously!
wind-up/ˈwaɪnd ʌp/ [countable noun]
▪ what was meant to be a harmless wind-up ended up with the sacking of three men yesterday.

children.name: be joking
children.definition: /be kiddinginformalto say sth that is not true as a joke :
examples: when he asked me to marry him i wasn’t sure whether he was joking or being serious.
just/only kidding
‘you’re just kidding, right mom?’ joe asked anxiously.
don’t get mad - i was only joking!
are you kidding?/you’re kidding!say this when you think someone is joking
you’re kidding. you mean it only rains once a year there?
‘they wanted $425 just for the room.’ ‘are you kidding?’
no kiddingsay this to show you are serious
it was the best pizza i’ve ever eaten, no kidding.
no kidding?say this when you think sb could be joking
she’s only sixteen? no kidding? she looks twenty-five.
